CORA; OR, THE VIRGIN OF THE SUN.
Performed for the first time on Monday, July 1799. The Music by Mr. SANDERSON; The Scenery by Mr. GREENWOOD; and the Machinery by Mr. BRANSCOMB.

CHARACTERS. PERUVIANS. Ataliba (King of Quito) Mr. Wallack Huescar (King of Cusco) Mr. Gibbons Zorimbo (Rolla's armour bearer) Mrs. Herbert Telasco (Father to Cora) Mr. Male Zorai (his Son) Mr. Simpson Capana (a Cacique) Mr. Pilbrow Standard Bearer Mr. Waldron, Jun. Pontiff Mr. Davis High Priest Mr. Myers Xaira Mr. d'Egville PRIESTS. Messrs. Williams, Swords, Kelly, &c. Caciques and Warriors of Ataliba's Party. Messrs. Wilkinson, Ridgway, Ireland, Jun. Herbert, Parsloe, Lother, Lonsdale, Trueman, &c. Caciques and Warriors of Huescar's Party. Messrs. Roberts, Ridgway, Porter, Mears, Sargeant, Jefferies, Smith, Fisher, &c. And Rolla Mr. Laurent SPANIARDS. Juan (Page to Alonzo) Miss Gray Diego (an Attendant on Alonzo) Mr. Montgomery And Don Alonzo de Molina Mr. Helme FEMALE PERUVIANS. Zulma (Mother to Cora) Mad. de la Croix Cora's Infant Sister Miss Fisher High Priestess of the Sun Miss Valois Amazilli Virgin of the Sun Mrs. Roffey Idali Virgin of the Sun Mrs. Wallack Peruvian flower Girl Miss Wallack VIRGINS OF THE SUN. Mrs. Fisher, Mrs. Jenkinson, Mrs. Smith, Mrs. Barrett, Mrs. Byrne, Miss Taylor, Miss Standen, &c. &c. PRINCIPAL DANCERS. Miss Adams, and the Miss Cabanels, and Cora Mrs. Wybrow

PART I. SCENE I. AN immense chain of mountains, down which torrents rush impetuously. An Indian discovered climbing a precipice, from which issues a cataract, that undermines the projection he has gained, and he is carried away with the torrentâANOTHER, viewing his fate, seeks for shelter in a tree, which, being struck by a column of fire, is consumed, and he falls.âAlonzo, his page Juan, and Diego, are discovered descending different parts of the mountains in the utmost distressâthunder, light'ning, wind, rain, &c.âsometimes they are visible, at others obscured.âAt length Alonzo descends, deprived of guides and companions. TRIO. Alonzo. Wandering beneath a dreary sky, What varied wrecks I'm doom'd to see; Lost in yon gulph my Indians lye, Their last bequest, wild misery! Perish'd alas! my friend, my guide! Juan (poor youth) my faithful page! (The Page descends assisted by Diego.) Diego. Master! Juan. âAlonzo! Diego and Juan. âValour's pride! Juan. The tempests wild, thy prayers assuage, Behold! the clouds dispersing fly! Alonzo. Ah, me! what havock here is made. Juan. I faint for succourâ Diego. âSo do Iâ Alonzo. Oh, death! thy stroke is but delay'd. Alonzo and Juan. We learn but from yon milder sky, Victims of hungerâwe must die. During the latter part of the trio the sky gradually clears, and a delightful calm succeedsâfatigued, and pressed by hunger and thirst, Alonzo dispatches Diego and Juan to procure fruits and water, they retire on opposite sides.âA BIRD flies across the stage, and Alonzo reclimes the mountains to kill it; but on his gaining the summit, A TYGER approachesâhe firesâthe tyger fallsâa scream is heard, and a number of Indians rush onâsome intimidated, others worshipping him.âAt length Capana (a hunter chief) with FOLLOWERS descend the mountains; and while Alonzo is endeavouring to ingratiate himself with the others, they seize and disarm himâ their chief viewing him with disdainâhe kneels supplicating. TRIO AND CHORUS. Alonzo. Pity a stranger, lost forlorn. Chief. Wretch! in thy garb a foe we trace, Destroyer of the human race, Spaniardâthy prayers but merit scorn! Alonzo. This heart ne'er pity's plea withstood, Think of a distant parent's moans! Chief. Our wives, our parents, childrens' groans, Bid this wing'd arrow drink thy blood! During this Alonzo is bound to a stake on a small eminence of the rock, and they prepare their bows and arrows to dispatch him. Alonzo. In your defence those arms I'd wield, The champion of humanity: Your friend, your brother, view in me! Female Indians Humanity then be thy shield. The Female Indians, as the men are on the point of discharging their arrows, place themselves, as a shield, before him. Chief. See Rolla our commander nigh! To him the victim we resign; His safety our's would undermine. Alonzo. See how a christian then can die! He appears ready, with intrepidity, to meet their arrowsâRolla eyes him with astonishment and admirationâas the Indians are once more preparing, OTHERS, on each side, bring on Juan and Diego bound, struggling. Alonzo. My vassals bound! hear, hear their plea, To serve your king was our design. Juan. Pity my youth. Diego. âAh, pity mine! The chief Indians now draw their arrows to the head, when Rolla, striking the earth with his lance, commands them to desist. Indians. Rolla commands, and ye are free! Rolla gives signs to liberate their prisonersâthey do so, and Alonzo is presented his arms. Alonzo. Thanks gallant chief, tho' you behold in me A Spaniard! I detest their cruelty! From Las Casas, your friend, I chearful bring, Congratulations to Ataliba your king. My fortune his, (with cruelty at strife) I offer him my allâmy swordâmy life! Exeunt Alonzo, &c. On the other side of the stage ENTER Telasco, Zorai and Zulma, leading on Cora, followed by Female Indians, and her Infant Sister.â Rolla views her with the utmost affection, kneels to herâshe informs him she must not hear a repetition of his passionâhe asks why?âXaira and Priests ENTER, to whom she is deliveredâafter affectionately taking leave of her former companions, who sing the following strainâ(Rolla keeping the centre of the stage lost in sudden terror and reflection) FEMALE INDIANS CHORUS. Cora farewellâthy race cÅlestial run, Chaste as purity's self-bride elect of the sun. The priests, Cora and her family exeunt on one side of the stage, followed by Rolla in a gloomy state of distraction, gazing after Cora; the Indians, &c. on the other. SCENE II. Outside View leading to the Temple of the Sun. Enter Cacique, Alonzo, Juan, and Diego. Female voices heard in the garden of the Temple of the Sun, joining in the following DUET AND CHORUS. While the sun's boundless blessings to chear us combine, To adorn his glad temple the chaplet entwine. In strains of delight, Enraptur'd unite, Soul of light! we adore thee! our consort divine! While Alonzo is listening to the above strains, Cora ENTERS, veiled, attended by her Relatives, Priests, &c.âAlonzo seems struck with her figure âthe door of the temple opens, and she is received by the Priestess, &c. and enters with some degree of trepidationâAlonzo's eyes following herâmusic is heard withoutâa shout of extacy from the multitude. CHORUS OF ATALIBA'S ATTENDANTS, without. âThe day's golden birth, bids us joyfully sing, âTo the god of his people, the worth of our king.â The Cacique informs Alonzo the king is near at hand, and proffers to conduct them to himâAlonzo looks mournfully towards the door Cora had entered, and follows himâDiego returns prying, and endeavours to peep through the doorâRolla rushes on wildly, looks at the temple, and fetches a sighâ seeing Diego prying, he seizes, and dashes him to the earthâDiego appears dreadfully alarmedâhe orders him to departâhe goes off much frightened âRolla appears mournfulâZorimbo, his bow-bearer, ENTERS, looks at Rolla, and shakes his head, knotting his quiposâRolla starts, and seeing him, asks his business. ZORIMBO âAIR. Oh! hapless chieftain, mournful I compose, The sad, sad history of Rolla's woes. BALLAD. The dangers of the raging fight, Undaunted Rolla dared to prove; His deeds attain'd fame's topmast height, But glory's sun now sinks in night. He yields, alas! to hopeless love! âFrom time no ray of hope appears, âThe gods his fatal wish reprove; âThe idol of his soul is theirs, âReligion claims her vows, her tears, âAnd Rolla yields to hopeless love!â E'en now the solemn signal's given, The virgins toward the temple move; Depriv'd thus of his earthly heaven, To wild despair sad Rolla driven. A victim yields to hopeless love. Rolla seems much agitated during this ballad, and goes off in perturbation, followed by Zorimbo. SCENE III. A Romantic View. Enter Diego runningâapes the conduct of Rolla to him in the former sceneâA Peruvian Flower Girl ENTERSâhe looks round with caution, and then approaches herâshe appears astonished âhe admires her flowersâtakes out a large purse, as if going to purchase some, but finds he is not in possession of a single dollar.âShe, admiring him, offers him flowersâhe receives them with extacy, and proceeding to make love, points to her golden ornamentsâshe smilesâhe speaks. RECITATIVEâDIEGO. Oh! what a roguish smile!âyes, yes (sighing) I'm done for! My blooming rose (chucking her under the chin) oh! no,âmy charming sun flower! He endeavours to engross her attention and affection âshe takes off the fillet from her head, and puts it on hisâhe struts aboutâshe smilesâhe puts his mulateer cap on herâwhile they are enjoying the exchange, Juan ENTERS, stamps with his foot, frowningly at Diego, and commands him to follow âhe does so, slyly beckoning the Peruvian after him. SCENE IV. The Inside of the Temple of the Sun. The image of the Sun upon an altar, raised some steps from the ground, on which that luminary reflects its brightest raysâthe olive branch on the altar. Emblematical Pas SeulâMiss Adams. The Youth of both Sexes, dressed in robes of light down, ENTER, with garlands to adorn the sacred columnsâas they dance round them, they encircle one another with their garlands, (this mysterious chain serving to typify the charms of that connection which the laws are to cement)â when thus in attitude, A Pas de Deux by the Miss Cabanals. A short figure ensues, and they, at the entrance of the procession, prostrate themselves inclined towards the altar.âEnter in Procession the Pontiff, High Priests, and Atalibaâthey all prostrate themselves, the king kneeling, before the altar. CHAUNTâATALIBA. Source inexhaustible of good! thy golden rays, Ripening our harvest, claim our warmest praise! Soft music heard withoutâXaira introduces the High Priestess, Virgins of the Sun, &c. followed in procession by Telasco, Idali, and Zorai; between the two former Cora is placed, veiled, Priestess and Zulma holding in their hands the end of that mysterious flame coloured girdle, the sign and pledge of that spotless chastity Cora devotes herself to maintainâthe high Priestess following. CHORUSâPriestesses and Virgins in Procession. Oh, delight of the world! our celestial spouse! Divine sire of Manco, receive a bride's vows. As they arrange themselves, Rolla rushes on in the utmost agitation, followed by Zorimboâ Ataliba, &c. approach the altarâCora bends before itâthe Priest unties the veilâshe, alarmed, seizes her mother's hand, and appears reluctantâTelasco bows to the altar requesting the Pontiff to proceedâ she imprints an ardent kiss on her father's cheekâ heaves a sigh, and approaches the altar nearerâ Rolla's agitation encreases. CHAUNTâHIGH PRIEST. In chastity pure as the sun's brightest rays, Unreproach'd 'till life's close must revolve Cora's days! The world's lost endearments no longer in view, She must bid to its joys an eternal adieu. Cora, much agitated, falls on the neck of her father, kisses him, and her brother, and sisterâher eye meets Rolla'sâthey tremblingly approach each other to take a last farewellâembraceâXaira, with religious awe, separates them, and she again reluctantly approaches the altar. THE PONTIFF PROCEEDS. But if our holy laws she violate, Hear trembling her, and her seducer's fate; A living grave his dreadful end will prove, A shameful death her sacrilegious love! Her sire, her brother, (kindred's dearest names) To expiate her guilt must perish in the flames; To heaven's high throne Cora religious bow, In conscious token of thy solemn vow. She, tremblingly, bends to the altarâRolla, delirious, is on the point of dispatching himself, but prevented by Zorimbo, who arrests his hand, and impells him to retire. PONTIFF to the High Priestess and Virgins. Children retireâCora, be it thy care, The sacrificial offerings to prepare! High Priestess and Virgins retire on one side with Cora, who, embracing her relatives, they retire on the otherâthe king comes forwardâENTER THE Cacique, (who had escorted Alonzo) followed by Alonzo and PageâAlonzo kneels at Ataliba's feetâpresents a pacquet, which Ataliba gives the Pontiff to peruse, then raises, and embraces himâ he waves the Pontiff forward, and pointing to the altar, the Pontiff brings down an olive branch which he presents Alonzo, who kisses it in token of peace and amity, and presents his sword and shield, which is deposited near the altarâHigh Priestess and Virgins RETURN with baskets of sacrificial breadâCora, crowned with flowers, is commanded by Xaira, and presents it to Ataliba kneeling, who commands her to present it to Alonzo âCora trembles as she offers the golden basketâ Alonzo views her with emotionâshe scarcely can prevent the basket from falling, and her trembling knees almost fail to convey her again to the Priestess, who supports herâTrumpet soundedâCapana (a Cacique) ENTERS in haste. RECITATIVEâCAPANA. Huescar, Cusco's Inca, noble chief, To every plea of amity is deaf; Our plains disfigur'd with a crimson flood, His sword already drinks your subjects' blood. ATALIBA. For retribution ev'ry bosom warms, Brave children of the sun, to arms, to arms. Warriors with their Caciques ENTER, and offer their services to Ataliba, and among the rest Alonzoâthe king beckons the Pontiff to him, and pointing to the altar, Pontiff brings forward Alonzo's sword and shield which he had deposited there âAtaliba girds on the sword, and the Pontiff presents him his shield. CHORUSâHIGH PRIEST, &c. Receive brave youth and nobly wield In virtue's cause the sword and shield: Our champion, counsellor, and friend, In peace a lamb, in war a lion be, Let Conquest's consort be humanity, And Pity's feeling Valour's steps attend. A double procession of the king, warriors, &c. on one side, and the Pontiff, Priests, &c. on the otherâAlonzo on one side, Cora on the other, bringing up the rearâthey exchange glances of affection at parting; and at the end of the procession the scene closes, Cora kneeling in solicitation for Alonzo's safety. SCENE V. Romantic View. Rolla ENTERS gloomilyâthe sound of the trumpet heardâhis bow-bearer (Zorimbo) follows hastilyâRolla asks him the causeâhe replies RECITATIVEâZORIMBO. You ask me why Exertion's on the wing? The answer's brief, to serve heav'n and our king! Rolla receives this intelligence with the utmost satisfaction, strikes the bow he gives him on the ground, and his Troops ENTERâRolla thanks heaven he can use that life in the cause of his country which would otherwise be a burthen to him, and commands his bow-bearer to cheer the troops, (who does so) with the following SONGâZORIMBO. [1.] When our country calls to arms, Native zeal enflames each breast; Fame displays her dauntless charms, In every martial splendor drest. Yet in pity's steps we tread, Nor cruelly war's weapon lave; When a prostrate foe shall plead, Our greatest glory be to save! 2. Invasion's threat can ne're affright, Our country's wrongs will lead us on; Justice shall guide us in the fight, And mercy when the battle's won. Then, if gasping on the field Some hero draws his latest breath, To soft humanity we'll yield, And weep for a brave soldier's death. At the close of the song, Rolla marches off his troops. SCENE VI. Huescar's TentâSun RiseâMartial Music. Enter Huescarâhis Chieftains following, bearing the banners of his tribeâhe prostrates himself before the sun. RECITATIVEâAccompanied Huescar. War's banners are unfurl'd; the god of day Lights us to vengeance on Ataliba! On Cayamburo's heights encamp'd they lie, Follow your chief to death or victory. As he is leading the troops off a trumpet sounds, and Alonzo, preceded by a Herald, and followed by Peruvians, with presents, ENTER. RECITATIVEâALONZO. Monarchâthis fatal difference I would heal, This war of brothers fain would I bid cease; The bond of social amity reseal, And blend endearments with returning peace. Huescar. So says Ataliba? this answer bear, I scorn his proffers urg'd by dastard fear; Blood must be shedâmy great revenge to sate, Unnumber'd enemies shall bite the dust! Alonzo. Their blood be on thy headâI yield to fateâ Thy foe, lov'd by his people, is as good as great: That king's invincible whose cause is just! Exit WITH FOLLOWERS. Huescar. Presumptuous reptile! at the Illapa's sound, Swear on my sword! No childish pity shall your souls debase. (They swear) (Kneeling) Thou sun adored! Blood! blood alone! can heal my honour's wound! Ambition's wishes can alone be crown'd, In total extirpation of a brother's hated race. March AND EXEUNT. SCENE VII. The Plains of Cayamburo intersected with treesâthe Heights interspersed with Peruvian encampments on the back groundâthe ascent and descent rendered practicableâtowards the front of the stage a prominent rock as an out-post. Trumpets and warlike music on each sideâthe illapa soundedâdifferent warriors meetâthe standard of the sun placed by a standard-bearer on the prominence. A General Battle TAKES PLACE. Ataliba's party drive Huescar's offâZulma and her Child descend the heights, the former scarcely knowing which course to take to elude pursuers, but most interested for the safety of her child.âZorai is attacked by TWO Caciques of the opposite party âZulma draws her arrow and dispatches the chief, who is aiming a blow at Zorai, who beats off the other Caciqueâanother party attack her, she endeavours to guard her child, and receives her death wound, the child exclaiming: RECITATIVEâCHILD. Save, save her life, Telasco! father, brother; She bleeds! she dies! my mother! oh! my mother. Zulma dies in the arms of her husband and son, and is born off on the shields of their party. The general Fight re-commences. The king is surrounded, and his life preserved by Alonzo, who, being wounded, is falling under the hand of his enemies, when Rolla, (who had ascended the rock, and seized the standard of the sun, in the act of doing which he receives a gash on his forehead with a club, and an arrow in his arm) leaps from the rock at the moment Alonzo is overcome, and receives the arrow in his breast aimed at Alonzo's life by HuescarâAlonzo recovers his weapon, and attacks Huescar driving him offâA Warrior attacks Rolla, who staggers, but still retains the standard for which they struggle, and he at length conquers his opponent âAtaliba ENTERS on one side with his party, Alonzo on the other with Huescar, &c. prisonersâthe characters groupe, and the prisoners, &c. are marched off. SCENE VIII. The Golden Garden of the Sun. Enter Cora melancholy, her action evincing the unsettled state of her mind. Enter AMAZILLA. RecitativeâAmazilla. Ah, Cora! why so melancholy grown? Restlessâsome secret preys upon thy mind, Poor solitary bird, why flutter thus alone? The presence of the bridegroom should cheer the new made bride. Cora shrinks at the name of bridegroom, but, recovering herself, bows to the sun, trembling at the former impurity of her wishes, and, heaving a sigh, is retiring when she is met by the High Priestess. TRIO. High Priestess. Why droop sweet maid? Forbear to sigh; Must I upbraid, Fair Cora?âfye! To heav'n allied, No earthly toils (The sun's sweet bride) Should cloud thy smiles, No, Cora, no! Dispel thy fears, Impurely flow Those causeless tears, In love most pure. Your heart his throne, Our godlike sire; His love has shewn, Then live for him And him alone. Amazilla. To hail the day! And glad the night; Joy's pinions play, In calm delight. Serenely blest, No busy thought Distracts the breast With poison fraught. No, Cora, no! Th'omnifick eye Beholds thy vow With extacy, In love most pure, &c. &c. (Martial music heard without) Enter IDALI. Idali. In accents delighting, To pleasure inviting; Triumphant's alighting, From victory's car, Our king; whose voice cheering His subjects, revering; Brings peace! which (endearing) O'er shadows each scar! Triumph's shouts, loud resounding, (Base traitors confounding;) Name Alonzo and Rolla, Our champions in war! They join in the latter part of the verse as a trioâ Cora's features, at the name of Alonzo, brightening into a smile. Exeunt EXULTINGLY. SCENE IX. Exterior View of the Temple of the Sun, behind which is a mountainous View. Enter Ataliba in triumphâRolla and Alonzo on each side followed by Caciques, Soldiers, &c. some guarding Huescar as an hostage. RECITATIVEâATALIBA. Guard well the hostage of returning peace, But treated as our kindred let him be; Misfortune claims compassion, 'twill decrease The constrain'd rigour of captivity! FINALE. Ataliba. Rolla! Alonzo! chiefs in honour's cause, Accept our thanksâa grateful monarch's prayer. He presents each with a rich embroidered scarf, as a token of affection for the services rendered him in the recent battle! Protectors of our altars, our liberty, and laws, (The people bow to them) My people view, exult with you! My people who're my children! my paternal care! Alonzo, Cacique, Juan, Chorus, and Ataliba. With heart, hand, and voice, Attune loyalty's string; A happy people's choice, Must reign a happy king! And curs'd be the traitor the golden band who'd sever, Long live my people! the king live for ever! Exeunt exultingly. The chorus dying away, Rolla returns followed by Zorimbo; he looks on the scarf bestowed on him by Ataliba, and, shaking his head, hints it only conceals a heart tortur'd with hopeless love; then gazes at the temple, intimating the object of his wishes is sequestered thereâthen sighs. ZORIMBO endeavouring to console him, Rolla forbear! why heave the hopeless sigh? Take thy last lookâ'twill wring thy tortur'd breast; By victory crown'd, a nation's wishes blest, In glory's blaze the fatal flame should die! Away! away! Madness attends your stay, Retireâretire awhile, and lull your griefs to rest! Rolla is unwillingly hurried off. ALONRO RE-ENTERS. Oh, Cora! belov'd! tho' depriv'd of thy view, My soul hovers near the abode it reveres; Oh! to hear but thy voice tho' it breath'd but adieu! To me wou'd be music more sweet than the spheres. While he is gazing on the templeâdistant thunder is heardâthe sky appears clouded, the earth agitated, the temple convulsed, and the mountainous volcano threatens an eruption. But hark! the distant thunder roars! The dark'ning sky a storm portends; Yon fiery gulph it's lava pours, In liquid flame the lake descends! The eruption commences with a dreadful crash, part of the temple gives wayâthe voices of the Virgins of the sun are heard complaining. Virgins. Oh! save us heaven! hear our moans! Alonzo. The temple totters! shrieks and groansâ Virgins. Oh! save us! Alonzo. Tell death's dreadful tale! Cora's retreat the flames assail! Shall dire destruction crush her charms? Cora. The love lorn Cora who will save? Alonzo. Her voice! I'll clasp her to my arms, Rescue or perish in her grave. Another part of the temple breakingâCora is seen clinging to a pillarâhe ascends the ruinsâshe faints in his arms, and for a period they are invisibleâ Rolla ENTERS, distracted, followed by Zorimbo. Virgins. Oh! heaven! thy pity we invoke! Zorimbo. Rolla assistance ne'er denies! See! see! he darts through clouds of smoke! Rolla rushes up the ruins followed by Zorimbo, when out of sight, Alonzo enters with Cora in his arms through a chasm in the temple. Alonzo. Open my love thine azure eyes! âTo gaze on this angelic form, âStern Virtue's self could not reprove; âMy throbbing heart 'gins her's to warm, âCora, awake to life and love! She wakes from her trance, views and embraces himâanother dreadful crashâHE BEARS HER OFF. Ataliba, Priests, &c. ENTERâa variety of characters discovered supplicatingâRolla in an attitude of despair near one of the columns. SUPPLICATING CHORUS OF Ataliba, Priests, Children, and Virgins. Oh! light supreme! thy mighty power, The world's extinction can command; On us mild peace and plenty shower, Or stretch Destruction o'er the land! Whate'er our crime just punishment fulfill, We yield unmurmuring to thy godlike will. END OF THE FIRST PART.
